author: Daniel Fienberg
title: â€˜A Very Royal Scandalâ€™ Review: Ruth Wilson and Michael Sheen Revisit Prince Andrewâ€™s â€˜Newsnightâ€™ Interview in Sturdy Amazon Miniseries
text:
Amazon enthusiastically announced the Sept. 19 release date for A Very Royal Scandal with the declaration, â€œThe critically acclaimed A Very â€¦ Scandal anthology is back!â€
My primary questions include: Was â€œScandalâ€ included so that nobody would think A Very Royal Scandal was, in some way, a part of a franchise that perhaps started with 1996â€™s A Very Brady Sequel ? Does your average television viewer even accept the existence of the A Very Dot Dot Dot Scandal franchise? And, perhaps most sincerely, even if we acknowledge that the A Very Dot Dot Dot Scandal franchise exists, what does it mean? What are the unifying characteristics between 2018â€™s A Very English Scandal , 2021â€™s A Very British Scandal and now A Very Royal Scandal , a trio of limited series without an overlapping character, star, writer or director?
The first two installments focused on pre-Internet kerfuffles stirred up by the British press, while A Very Royal Scandal is set in the past decade and practically features social media notifications as a main character. English and British were essentially acting two-handers, driven by the interplay between Hugh Grant and Ben Whishaw and between Claire Foy and Paul Bettany, respectively while Royal lets stars Ruth Wilson and Michael Sheen interact for maybe 25 minutes in the middle of the series and thatâ€™s it. So I guess that more than anything, what distinguishes A Very Dot Dot Dot Scandal as a franchise is the presence of Blueprint Pictures as a producer, the three-episode running time and, perhaps, the quality, since all three entries are quite good.
Plus, the whole A Very Dot Dot Dot Scandal thing is a good distraction, because otherwise the only way to introduce A Very Royal Scandal to people is, â€œHey, remember Netflixâ€™s Scoop , the movie from April about the notorious Newsnight interview with Prince Andrew? This is that. Again. Totally. But theyâ€™re both entertaining, if you like that sort of thing.â€ The extra running time here â€” Scoop was a tight 103 minutes â€” lets the miniseries flesh out some of the main charactersâ€™ feelings before and after the main event, but if you find those additions more than a little unconvincing, they arenâ€™t necessarily an asset.
For those who havenâ€™t seen Scoop , writer Jeremy Brock and director Julian Jarrold place the Newsnight interview in the middle of the second episode and dedicate the most enjoyable part of the series to the build-up.
We meet Prince Andrew (Sheen), beloved second-born of the unseen reigning monarch and petulant brother to the unseen ascending monarch. Andrew, who drops reference to his military service in the Falklands into nearly every conversation, is a doting father to two daughters (Honor Swinton Byrneâ€™s Beatrice and Sofia Oxenhamâ€™s Eugenie) and an amiable ex-husband to the brash but caring Fergie (Claire Rushbrook). He was also, at some point, a close chum to Jeffrey Epstein (an uncanny John Hopkins). As a result, he has weathered minor tempests tied to Epstein and even salacious accusations from one of Epsteinâ€™s victims. While he has avoided public comment on the subject, it arises again after Epsteinâ€™s death in 2019.
That brings us to Emily Maitlis (Wilson), Newsnight presenter and A Very Royal Scandal executive producer. Maitlis is widely revered, but she has faced her own challenges tied to a longtime stalker and, more recently, connected to accusations of bias stemming from an ill-timed, if thoroughly justified, on-air eye roll. After Epsteinâ€™s death, Maitlis is determined to get the first candid sit-down with Prince Andrew. She does. They discuss Pizza Express and perspiration. Ignominy ensues.
Because the interview is the interview and it wasnâ€™t that long ago, A Very Royal Scandal , like Scoop before it, thrives as a prelude. The conversation itself is just two great performers reenacting clips you could watch on YouTube.
Using ticking clocks as an aggressive motif to build suspense â€” Maitlis is very digital, Prince Andrewâ€™s entire world is analogue â€” A Very Royal Scandal focuses on developing the personalities of its two principal figures. It underlines their respective goals in the Newsnight special, setting them up for how theyâ€™ll react once it goes wide and the world reacts, which is the entirety of the third hour.
As played by Wilson (and, actually, as interpreted by Gillian Anderson in Scoop ), Maitlis is anxious and insecure with a tendency toward blundering, but with a remarkable ability to click into action under pressure. Sheâ€™s infuriated by the state of modern journalism, sheâ€™s outraged by the way that female body language is sanctioned in a way nobody ever does with men â€” echoing the minor pockets of outrage at Kamala Harrisâ€™ reactions to Donald Trump in their debate â€” and sheâ€™s a calculating metaphorical chess player with an excellent team, led by Ã‰anna Hardwickeâ€™s Stewart MacLean and Clare Calbraithâ€™s Sam McAlister (the Billie Piper role from Scoop ).
As played by Sheen (very differently from Rufus Sewellâ€™s more glowering Scoop take), Prince Andrew is all insulated insecurity, a man who has never gotten a straight answer from anybody in his life and still doesnâ€™t feel good about himself. Andrewâ€™s bumbling nature is done no favors by the padded suits and troweled makeup that never really transform Sheen, but abet the actorâ€™s semi-comic approach. Andrewâ€™s own team includes the Queenâ€™s private secretary Edward Young (Alex Jennings), who only wants Andrew to vanish before Her Majestyâ€™s Platinum Jubilee, and Andrewâ€™s own private secretary Amanda Thirsk (Joanna Scanlan), who is again treated as the myopic architect of this PR disaster.
For two hours, A Very Royal Scandal is tightly cut and smartly observed and strategized without being revelatory, despite Maitlisâ€™ direct involvement. As talky as the drama is, Jarrold and production designer Noam Piper march the action through varied posh domestic spaces, giving viewers, who might think they know the plot and the settings, a rewarding sense of voyeurism. Even when we expect the direction to stick to the visual language of Newsnight , Jarrold opts instead for tight close-ups that bring out the best in both lead actors.
The final hour, the one meant to reflect on the significance of the cultural moment and its aftermath, is faultier in its approach. Maitlis comes to understand that the broadcast may have made the story about her and marginalized Epsteinâ€™s victims in a series that, by its very nature, makes the story about Maitlis and marginalizes Epsteinâ€™s victims. The borderline hypocrisy plays as more self-serving than self-aware. It doesnâ€™t help that while A Very Royal Scandal makes no gestures to vindicate Prince Andrew â€” heâ€™s a hubristic doofus â€” the show seems increasingly sympathetic, in part because Eugenie and especially Beatrice are very present and Byrne and Oxenham engender a lot of empathy, and in part because the rest of the Firm/Crown is so beastly to Andrew, whether he deserves it or not.
It leads to a disappointingly flat and speculative conclusion to a saga that has proven, for the second time this year, to be gripping.
Now bring on A Very Brady Scandal .

author: FOX 5 Atlanta
title: Parents of College Park volleyball player who collapsed, died hires high-profile attorney | FOX 5 Atlanta
text:
Parents of College Park volleyball player who collapsed, died hires high-profile attorney Updated December 19, 2024 7:44pm EST College Park FOX 5 Atlanta Share
Copy Link Email Facebook Twitter LinkedIn Reddit Mother of volleyball player: 'She could have been saved' The family of a teenage volleyball player who collapsed at practice in College Park and later died is now working with a famed civil rights attorney. Ben Crump will represent the family of Amanda Sylvester.
The Brief The Sylvester family has hired attorney Ben Crump to investigate the death of their daughter, Mandy, who collapsed during volleyball practice and later died. There was a significant delay in emergency response, with an ambulance arriving nearly an hour after the initial 911 call, which was initially categorized as low acuity. Mandy's parents believe that quicker emergency response could have saved her life, and they are seeking accountability to prevent similar incidents. Crump criticized the emergency response protocols and has requested an independent autopsy to determine Mandy's cause of death. The family expressed their grief and frustration, emphasizing the importance of timely help in emergencies. COLLEGE PARK, Ga. - The parents of Amanda "Mandy" Sylvester, a 15-year-old who collapsed during volleyball practice and later died, have hired prominent civil rights and personal injury attorney Ben Crump to investigate the circumstances surrounding their daughterâ€™s death.
Anthony and Barbara Sylvester stood alongside Crump at a press conference Thursday, demanding accountability and seeking to prevent similar tragedies.
Amanda "Mandy" Sylvester (Supplied)
What happened to Mandy Sylvester? "We waited... we waited... we waited," said Barbara Sylvester, recalling the moments after her daughter collapsed on Dec. 5 at the Tracey Wyatt Recreation Center. Bystanders called 911, but an ambulance from Grady EMS did not arrive until nearly an hour later.
According to Grady Health System, the initial emergency call was categorized as low acuity, meaning Mandyâ€™s condition was not considered life-threatening. A second 911 call prompted an upgrade to high acuity, but by then, Mandyâ€™s mother had already rushed her to Childrenâ€™s Healthcare of Atlanta at Hughes Spaulding Hospital.
"All I could think is if I could just get her to the doctor, sheâ€™d be okay," said Barbara Sylvester.
FULL VIDEO: Mother speaks about volleyball player death Family and attorney of 15 year old Amanda Sylvester hold news conference Thursday afternoon after teen dies during practice.
Mandy arrived at the hospital at 7:20 p.m. Doctors revived her heart after it stopped once, but she was pronounced dead at 8:40 p.m.
Mandy, who lived with Type 1 diabetes, was wearing a monitor linked to her motherâ€™s phone. However, her family insists her death was unrelated to the condition.
Anthony Sylvester, her father, believes quicker action could have saved his daughter. "She could have been saved had someone responded. Had someone done something," he said.
Crump, known for representing families in high-profile cases, emphasized the failures he believes occurred that night. "For an ambulance not to show up for almost an hour, that is horrifying to every parent," Crump said.
FULL VIDEO: Father speaks about volleyball player death Family and attorney of 15 year old Amanda Sylvester hold news conference Thursday afternoon after teen dies during practice.
He also criticized emergency response protocols. "Whether itâ€™s Grady Hospital EMS or College Park Fire and Rescue, there were mistakes made from the very start. Weâ€™re going to get to the bottom of it. We owe it to Amanda. We owe it to this community."
Crump and his team have requested an independent autopsy to determine Mandyâ€™s cause of death.
SEE ALSO:
College Park volleyball player collapses, dies: Probe launched into lack of ambulance response College Park volleyball player collapses, dies: Grady EMS gives timeline of requested response College Park volleyball team heartbroken, angry after teen's death at practice Barbara Sylvester echoed the familyâ€™s grief and frustration. "When you call for help, help should come."
For the Sylvester family, Dec. 5 is a date they will never forget. "The night of December fifth will forever be etched into the Sylvester family consciousness," said Anthony Sylvester. "Itâ€™s the day our youngest child, our only girl, collapsed and never came home."
The Source: This article is based on details released during a press conference on Thursday attended by FOX 5's Alli Levine.

author: WAM
title: Ramadan 2024: Sheikh Zayed Grand Mosque receives 570,113 visitors during first half of holy month - News | Khaleej Times
text:
During the first half of the Holy Month of Ramadan, the Sheikh Zayed Grand Mosque in Abu Dhabi received 570,113 visitors.
This total included 164,704 individuals attending prayers, 194,978 guests, and 210,431 individuals partaking in iftar gathering. At the same mosque, 102,419 individuals performed the Isha and Taraweeh prayers.
Meanwhile, the Sheikh Khalifa Grand Mosque in Al Ain and the Sheikh Zayed Grand Mosque in Fujairah recorded 77,233 and 50,456 worshippers, respectively.
The Sheikh Zayed Grand Mosque Centre has spread its mobile information stations across its grounds to accommodate the surge of devotees for the final 10 days of Ramadan, to cater to the needs of devotees, address their questions, and guide them to various locations.
Furthermore, the centre has improved its switchboard services by doubling its number of staff to efficiently handle the increased volume of calls and inquiries during this period.
The mosque also scheduled the Tahajjud night prayer at 12am and visiting hours will conclude at 11.30pm throughout the week, for the duration of this period.
Approximately 1,500 carpets In readiness for the concluding 10 days of the holy month, the centre has outfitted the mosque's courtyard with approximately 1,500 carpets. To facilitate the movement of devotees from parking areas to the prayer halls, 70 electric vehicles have been deployed, which will prioritise the elderly and those with special needs. The mosque is also equipped with 50 wheelchairs and 3,515 seats to ensure the comfort of worshippers.
Moreover, in collaboration with the Abu Dhabi Civil Defence Authority, ambulances are on standby, and a civil defence team will be stationed at the mosque.
Provision of additional parking spaces to facilitate access during the last 10 days of Ramadan The centre has ensured convenient access to the mosque by arranging 8,379 parking spaces for devotees. Specifically, 1,500 spots are dedicated to women near the northern prayer halls, while 60 spots are reserved for individuals with disabilities.
This year, in collaboration with authorities, the centre has added 1,800 parking spaces on Grand Mosque Street opposite Gate of Coexistence - Number 7, as well as at other locations, including Zayed Sports City, Erth Hotel, and near the Oasis of Dignity.
A shuttle bus service to the mosque is also available from these locations to support the influx of worshippers attending the Tahajjud night prayers during the last ten days of Ramadan.
Distribution of 960,431 iftar meals as part of the "Our Fasting Guests" project Throughout the Holy Month of Ramadan, the Sheikh Zayed Grand Mosque Centre has implemented the "Our Fasting Guests" initiative, which honours the legacy of the late Sheikh Zayed bin Sultan Al Nahyan by distributing iftar meals daily at the mosque and workers' cities, in partnership with Erth Hotel.
During the first half of the holy month, the project successfully distributed 960,431 iftar meals, with 210,431 being served at the mosque and some 750,000 delivered to workers' cities, in collaboration with the Higher Corporation for Specialised Economic Zones (ZonesCorp) in Abu Dhabi.
The Sheikh Zayed Grand Mosque Centre has also enlisted 580 volunteers to work alongside the centre's employees, the Emirates Red Crescent, police officers, paramedics and the civil defence.
